Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: Some scientific foundations to select topics in biology, especially those we see in the headlines today.
Learned very little - some rote memorization about biology, but very little that I didn't already know.
I learned about large major issues about diseases and biology all in one.
I learned a lot about the biology of life, such as cells, organisms, diseases, and more.
I learned a lot about contemporary biology, especially more about the brain, plants, and diseases.
CARLSON IS THE GOAT.
Improved knowledge about the science and the issues behind many of today's challenges.

I got a basic understanding of pressing biological issues, and I learned how to read scientific literature without stumbling over confusing terms/concepts. Related to that: I also gained a basic scientific vocabulary that I think will be useful to me in my college career - in order to understand more complicated concepts in this course, it was necessary to first understand basic biology that applied pretty universally to whatever we were talking about.
I learned how to write a scientific paper that discusses a social issue. I also had to relearn how to study for science exams which was helpful.
Biology in an ethical light and the consequences behind the science.

This class will teach you literally nothing. It's all rote memorization and the professors make it seem all jolly fun but in reality they're there to screw you over and make all the material seem easier then it is and then put questions on the exam that are unclear and frankly ridiculous.
I learned a lot about the economic/social effects of diseases and about scientific issues in general.
I learned about relevant scientific issues, such as infectious disease, mental illness, and climate change. I also learned how to read scientific literature.
I learned a ton. The course is very well geared towards learning. It's kinda like spending 2 hours each week watching TED talks--not crazy in-depth, but super informative and thought-provoking.
High school level biology.
I developed further knowledge of biology and the issues associated politically around the world with it.
I was able to learn so much more about how science and society truly co-exist and must work in tandem for mutual understanding and progress to occur.
Understand the effects diseases have on the world, socially, culturally, financially, etc.

Gained a pretty good basic knowledge on a wide array of topics in biology. I came into the course with very little biology knowledge due to poor prior education and I feel like after this course I have a much better understanding about basic biological processes.

I learned a lot about a wide variety of topics in science, and I also learned to question and explore the contexts of various innovations in science and certain phenomena, such as epidemics or even discoveries.
I learned a vast amount of information on several areas of biology in just a short amount of time. Very interesting course
My fascination for the biological world is renewed.
memorization, memorization, memorization.
I learned the biology behind current political issues.

As the name suggests, we covered all sorts of issues in biology; from the implementation issues that arise in combatting malaria, the potential social concerns about GMOs or gene editing technology or the concerning  effects of Global Warming on biodiversity, and  ocean acidification.
I think having the science background behind some social issues was really important. It explained the background behind some issues i was already vaguely familiar with, which was really interesting.
Understanding of science concepts that I wouldn't otherwise get
Basic knowledge of biological concepts and processes as well as current controversial issues pertaining to biology.

In this class, I learned a lot about biological issues that are present in society today. In this way, the class was very relevant and provided significant information regarding issues that we face every day.
I learned about controversial topics in science and the politics behind them.
I learned about how various biological problems are connected to important social issues.
A general understanding of biology concepts and how they apply to real-world problems. However, I don't think I learned particularly more about these issues than in my AP bio class.
I learned a lot about bacteria and drug abuse.
This is great for people who want to learn about important scientific policy

Overall, I thought the course was a good survey of different types of ways that biology and societal issues intersected. We started off the semester with global diseases/viruses, bacteria, etc., then proceeded to plants/agriculture/warming, then ended with a mix of neuroscience/drugs/addiction and some other smaller subjects.
General science knowledge

I learned more about basic biology and how it affects our modern world, namely through a social sciences perspective. Information about drug abuse and climate change seemed to be the most relevant to my interests.
I gained insight in the biological underpinnings of certain social issues.

This course taught me the basic biology behind many issues facing society today, such as different epidemics, neurological disorders, and global warming. We also discussed the societal implications of these topics and explored one of them in depth through the final paper.
Learned basic introduction to biological structures and their larger social implications.
Note taking and writing
I learned a general overview of biology, especially how biology interacts with our society.

General knowledge about science, diseases, and their impacts on society/economy. I'd say most of the information was pretty general. You touch the surface-level of the science behind these processes and some basic societal impacts.
Good basic overview of biology
I learned a lot about the science behind widespread diseases, the biology of plants, and various mental disorders. A great course for learning the foundations of biology!

This course is really just about memorizing mass amounts of information and regurgitating it on exams. It is too much information to realistically retain from exam to exam. So while I memorized lots of cool facts about schizophrenia and malaria or whatever, I couldn't tell you what they were now.
I learned a lot about the social issues regarding topics in the scientific world today. I also learned how these topics may affect us in ways more than we realize.
I don't feel like I learned any major concrete things in this class but I guess I learned some cool facts.
You didn't need to know anything prior the course although prior exposure to Biology would help
An introductory course on diseases, plants, and mental disorders.
The course offers a good grounding in biology-related social, economic, and political issues, especially for non-STEM majors.

The biology itself is not too advanced (I myself did not take AP Bio, so I did learn some new concepts) and I found the social/historical connections made to be very interesting. The professors take special care to make the class interesting, which helped a lot with engagement.
I gained a working knowledge of a variety of subjects, all including basic biological foundations.
How to connect biological knowledge to daily life
A basic knowledge of biology and relating issues
I really enjoyed this course, as a pre-med, for the wider view of science it gave me than any of my other med school prerequisites.
Great overall understanding of very relevant scientific themes.

In some ways, this course built upon concepts that I had learned about in high school but forgot. In other ways this course exposed me to new concepts (especially in regards to the plants/environment section).

I learned a huge amount about basic science behind daily life and the world. I specifically found the topics regarding disease, global warming ramifications, mental health and micro-biome interesting and relevant to non-science students.
I learned about science and the sociopolitical issues that revolve around it.
Biology behind various hot topics and phenomena in biology. Insights: the social political and economic factors that influence  research and solutions.
Critical thinking, engaging with material from many viewpoints, understanding of the social issues interconnected with biology

I learned a lot about diseases, plants, and the human brain by taking this course! It was absolutely fascinating and I learned a lot of information that will be useful to know in everyday life, such as information about GMOs, disease transmission, and mental illnesses. I really enjoyed learning all of this science and how it relates to society. It's a great class because the science you learn is interesting and relates to everyday life, even if you're not a science major.

Strength is the material itself - it can actually be pretty interesting. Weakness is that the three exams are simply exercises in rote memorization. Can be frustrating and feel sort of disconnected from the rest of the class.

Lectures were somewhat engaging, but tests didn't examine the concepts discussed in class or the issues surrounding these topics. Rather, they were purely memorization of the slides, and often asked questions about minute details that were barely discussed in class. The class rewards the wrong sort of learning.
Strengths - everything about this course was great, every lecturer was amazing, funny, and engaging.

The sections suck. They're led by TAs who don't allow you to do well unless you're the section asshole, which no one wants to be. They're uninteresting and unrelated to the lectures, so they seem pointless and no one wants to be there, which makes participation that much harder. The class itself was interesting but the exams were way harder than the intensity level of the class itself.

Strengths: lectures are pretty good, most of the material is interesting, professors are engaging, and TAs are genuinely interested in the class.

Weaknesses: the midterms are each written by a different team so vary drastically. For instance, the second midterm was completely unlike the first, despite TAs assuring that it would be similar. The practice questions circulated for the second midterm had nothing to do (literally no overlap in terms of topic or content) with a single question on the second midterm. A little more transparency on what is expected on midterms would be appreciated.

This course could be improved in that section was much more engaging than lecture and the questions asked on the exams seemed to be punishing students and looking for random facts, rather than actual comprehension and understanding of the material.
Make it 2/3 midterms.

It keeps things interesting and relevant to current events without going too in depth to the details of the science involved. Tests sometimes focused on nitty details from lectures that didn't have much relevance to the big ideas of the topics.

A strength of this course is that for the most part, material was well-suited to non-majors and framed in an understandable way (I would say Gendron's lectures might have been the exception; they were far more difficult to grasp). That is an expected strength, as most people take this because they hear it's an easy science credit. The biggest weakness - and it is a big one - is the organization of the course. It was extremely unclear who was writing the exams at any given point, what would be covered on the exams, what we were expected to know from lecture, and what information was supplementary. I would say it is also not conducive to a student's learning to have three different lecturers, particularly because the first, Prof. Carlson, is by far the best, and students are likely evaluating their potential success/interest in the course based on his lectures, and might be thrown for a curveball later on (as I was). Performance on the second test tended to go down, maybe as a result of this -- the specificity of certain questions on exams were also a major, major weakness. The course needs to focus more on concepts, less on minutia, if it is indeed a course for non-majors.

The strengths were the interesting lectures, the weaknesses were that the exams were not always what was expected. In review sessions it was stated to focus on certain things and then those topics were not on the exam at all.
very good biology overview, solid class for nonSTEM majors.

I guess there is music in the beginning but otherwise, there is no strength to this class. The course director Rachel is opaque and doesn't really care about doing her job. She sits there, turns on the lights every once in a while and that's it. The exams are unclear, the material is rote memorization, and the topics are dull.
I loved this first section of the course, hated the second, and liked the third. The second was absolutely unbearable. Get rid of it.

Strengths: Good survey of different scientific concepts, instructors were engaging, straightforward material, relevant topics. Weaknesses: Very large class (many students who were off-task), incorrect time allotted to course (it never lasted past 12:30, but the official time allotted to the course was 11:35-12:50 - lecturers would rush to finish by 12:30 needlessly)
I think this course is incredibly well structured and fulfills its purpose as well as any course I have ever taken.

Strength: material is easy enough for anyone to understand
Weakness: workload & easyness of material actually makes it hard to be motivated for this class.
The strengths are the professors that taught the curriculum but the weakness would be preparation for the exam

I wish the professors would have been on the same page on the difficulty of exams because with each professor it seemed the expected knowledge shifted and it made it hard to study for the exams. The strengths however were the variety of areas we studied and were exposed to.

Overall I thought the course did a good job of appealing to non-science majors and making the scientific topics understandable and relatable for us. The only thing I would change was making an effort to go over more fully the specific scientific processes we learn about since those are what show up on the exams.

The course had a very manageable workload, and I liked the opportunity to learn from different professors each month about different topics. Each professor was very knowledgable, and it was a great opportunity to be exposed to many issues that affect us today.

The course covered a lot of interesting topics and the professors were engaging. However, I did not like the way students were evaluated. The exams were strictly fact memorization, so I felt as though I wasn't able to absorb the material in an effective way. A lot of memorization is required for the exams, but I think a better way to test the students would be with more comprehensive questions or short answer. Memorizing and writing down facts doesn't incentivize students to actually learn the interesting material.

I think there were some gaps between what we were taught in the lecture and what came up on the exams. The information we were taught and asked about was very precise, even though the powerpoints were generally vague and not precise.

I almost never missed lecture. They were easy to follow and I listened intently. But it was difficult to nail the information perfectly and then it wasn't available anywhere else to revise from. That was tough.
The testing epectations could have been made clearer. Often Id feel i was rote memorizing teh slides only to find that they wanted different answers instead.

I thought the lecture topics and lecturers were extremely engaging, but one thing that bothered me was that the test topics were incredibly specific while the lecturers only highlighted more general topics.
2nd test by Professor Carlson was unfair

I though that the course was really great! The TAs were all super nice and the professors really wanted to teach! I felt like the first exam was very memorization based, more than the others, and I think that it could have been more conceptual.
Having three different lecturers was fun. I liked that a lot. I'm not sure that it could be improved.
It's strengths are in the lectures, and the weaknesses are in section.
The lectures were very clear and I liked the variety of professors and topics.
Exams were very open-ended, sometimes hard to know what the professors are looking for in the answer.

All of the professors in this course were great. Additionally, the material presented was interesting and relevant. Overall, this course was very strong. Sometimes, however, the exams were worded in a confusing way or seemed to reflect information that wasn't particularly stressed as important in lecture.
It was hard to tell what was important to know for the exams sometimes, and discussion about the actual issues in biology was only really relevant to section.

The best lecturer was the first-- he was excellent at explaining concepts, and applying them to interesting historical and political themes. 


However, often other lectures were often very disorganized and the chosen exam material didn't seem to correlate in significance to what was discussed in lectures.
Weakness theres no textbook. Strengths - the professors are awesome.
The material is interesting. One of the exams was not what we were told to study.

Strengths: all three professors were incredibly engaging and good at laying out important material in a clear way. I had a wonderful Teaching Fellow (Anna) who definitely helped all of us in her section do better in the course. The content of the course is interesting and the topics are broadly relevant. There is an appropriate and fair workload. Weaknesses: I thought some of the issues related to opioid abuse and addiction were handled in a heavy-handed way. For all professors but Gendron and Koleske in particular, the slides really did not reflect a lot of the content they expected you to know on the midterms. So if your in-class notes weren't amazing, you basically had no way of studying for the things you were tested on. I think the professors need to work a little bit harder to make sure that they provide the testable content in some way other than verbally, because it makes it really hard to study otherwise.
Section could be more productive and streamlined, focusing on explaining the topics discussed in class in a more in depth manor.
Section 3 was hard to follow, the rest was great

I liked that there were three professors-- it was refreshing. I also liked my TA, Anna a lot. I will say that the constant turnover of subject matter made it hard to actually learn any of it thoroughly, because nothing was cumulative.

I came into this course with a pretty strong science background - AP Biology, essentially - and thought it could be more challenging, or get more into the depth of certain scientific pathways (ex. action potential in a neuron) without necessarily testing on that material. The exams seemed to be based primarily on memorization of the facts on the slides the professors had, which were posted, so it wasn't terrible- but I thought the random information we had to memorize covered more breadth and was scattered than true depth/knowledge of a given topic.
too much specific information

Essay: have TA break down the rubric, with them emphasizing imoortance if the social part. And have then clarify what needs to be clarified. I got points off for exolanimg the science of a certain thing without citing, because I thought it fell under the category is common knowledge.

Tests:clarify on the first test that is testing the SCIENCE and not really the social issues. Need to know the names of bacteria shapes, etc

Rachel was amazing, the professors were good too and tried to make the content engaging. However, we were in no way prepared for the tests, the grading on tests, sections, and the final paper was entirely arbitrary.
The grading for the paper seemed unfair, but the classes were interesting and i enjoyed section.

Throughout the course,  the professors made the information accessible to students and made concepts interesting to learn. However, one of the largest weaknesses were the TAs, who were confusing during midterm review sessions and led to students doing worse on some exams, and the structure of the exams fluctuated in a way that made the course much more difficult.

This course is a really great survey course for those without a strong science background. I found the lectures engaging and relevant, even though I wasn't expecting them to be, and the professors are all really knowledgeable and fun. The workload is definitely manageable and the readings are mostly journalistic articles rather than scientific papers, which I liked. Since the three professors each write an exam, it's a little hard to know what to expect on them because they're all different.

Strengths are the broad scientific foundation provided to social problems. Many topics covered. Also enjoyed the sections

Weaknesses are the lack of communication between the TFs and teachers about exams that made preparation extremely difficult. The expectations for assignments were extremely confusion. In addition, it would have been good for the sections to reiterate the material from class.
Writing and speaking in section

Strengths: how it is structured. I really like the three modules idea and how there is an exam at the end of each module, as it takes a lot of the stress off the class. Additionally, there is no final exam (just a third module exam), which is great. 

Weaknesses: the quality of the TFs was not consistent, some were great but others were unhelpful both in answering questions about the biology content (since at their grad school level they specialize in very specific things) and general requirements of the course

Interesting material, lectures were pretty decent, sections kind of depended on your TF. In general, an okay class if you need a science credit but don't want to go too deep into the scientific backing.
A little too survey oriented in class but exams were more detail focused

A well-structured course overall. The learning objectives at the beginning of each lecture were great in terms of making expectations clear. Sometimes there was a bit of conflicting information, but it's understandable because this class doesn't go very in-depth.

This course was good in that it helped me learn information at a high level, but the grading seemed arbitrary - consistently arbitrary in that the tfs all grade the same question on exams, but arbitrary nonetheless. I think this course should do a better job of outlining exactly what information will be on the exams as for several of our tests, the "learning objectives" heavily emphasized by the professors in class, weren't even the material on which we were tested. I think that the grades and exam performance is a poor reflection of what information students learned and could apply. Instead the grades are reflections of whether students took note of minute details on slides.

Strengths: engaging, relevant, and sensible teaching structure. 
Weaknesses: pace is very fast, and test questions are not always from seemingly important lecture material.
Disorganized style. The tests are too hard and I thought it was hard to get a good grade.

I found the materials taught in the first and third sections very interesting and engaging, but less so for the second section which is about plants. It would be interesting to make it more human centered.

Interesting lectures and readings. Loved the final paper. Tests caught a number of students off guard because they were more specific than expected, so perhaps it would be good to help students get a better idea of what tests will be like.

Strengths: course really tries to be interesting and well-rounded
Weaknesses: some of the professors were a little unorganized and sometimes focused more on making students laugh than on explaining concepts in an understandable way

Professor Carlson was definitely a strength, he was a very engaging professor. It was well geared towards those without a scientific background. The paper was the most difficult, it called on a level of skill in communication in this field that wasn't touched on at any other time in the class.
the tests do not always align with the course material and were very poorly worded. The TFs were really great and helpful.

Strengths: all the professors are very funny and knowledgeable, the lessons are enjoyable
Weakness: no profound investigation into each of the topics
How to improve: reduce the number of topics and expand on the depth of each one
This class is a solid science credit for those without a science background
I would say that the lack of consistent themes is a weakness. The course sacrifices depth for breadth.
Some parts were a bit too simplified. While I understand this course is geared towards humanities majors (such as myself) I would have enjoyed more intellectual challenge.
I enjoyed the content discussed in lecture and section. However, I do feel like the tests got progressively harder and were not always a fair representation of main concepts learned in class.
Weakness was that some of the exam questions were unnecessarily specific testing memorization rather than knowledge.
This class is not very well organized - the TFs would often not know what material would be on the exam, and sometimes the exams would not be written well.
The tests were confusing and review sessions were lacking.

The course was very well structured! The lectures were clear, and material was presented in an engaging way. The readings sometimes felt superfluous, in that the same topics were discussed in sufficient detail in the lectures, but I thought they were interesting. Perhaps if we were assigned more complex readings that we were then tested on, or if we discussed the readings themselves in lecture or section, that would help integrate them better into the course.

I really liked the structure of the class. I liked that there were three different professors who taught three different segments of the class; this allowed for me to learn about diverse areas of biology from experts in their fields. I also liked that there were midterm exams at the end of each section. I thought the exams were overall fair and I appreciated that there were three of them to test our knowledge.
Good science credit. If nothing else, it's pretty interesting and the professors are great.
No - its not as easy of a science credit as people make it out to be (The average on the two tests were an 82 and 83) , and isn't engaging.
yes! If you are looking for a science credit that isn't biologically based, take this. The professors rock and lectures are fun.
I'd only recommend this to class to other people who have to take a science credit and want something easy. I wouldn't recommend it to any one who doesn't have to take it.

A great science credit for a non-science major. If you've taken AP Bio, a lot of the content is pretty similar and easy to pick up. Study for the three midterms, go to class and section, and write the 6 page final paper and you're set. None of these is really that difficult if you put in some effort, and most of it is pretty interesting. I'm really glad I took this as my science credit, I actually enjoyed most of the lectures and topics. Take it for Professor Carlson alone!
GUT.
Great science credit that gives you material to talk about important issues facing society. Very useful class but not difficult if you pay attention in class. Best of both worlds!

Overall, sure. However, I would recommend that any student go into this course knowing that it is not necessarily an easy A unless you're good at straight memorization, and that the bureaucratic nature of the course can make it difficult to be successful (organization is TERRIBLE; none of the TAs knew what was going to be on the exam at any given time but would act in review sessions as though they did. There seems to be a weird hierarchy of knowledge, and no one knows who is writing the tests (TAs or profs)). The easiest way to be successful in the course is memorizing the slides, which is somewhat sad - if you're trying to really understand concepts, you've come to the wrong place. My friends who are good at memorization loved this class. My friends who are bad at memorization but enjoy science hated it. That probably says something. That being said, though, 2/3 units (Carlson's and Koleske's) were really interesting, and I enjoyed lectures on these topics. Gendron's unit was not, though I'm not sure whether that's because of his subject matter or because he wasn't overly adept at explaining concepts, considering none of us have a science background (I'm assuming).

I'd definitely recommend this course to another student because the content is relevant to the real world. Also, learning about the social/economic/political impacts of biology was both fun and informative.
Yes, because it is a good science credit for non science major which is very nice.
Yes, I think it is a great class, especially for incoming freshmen.

Absolutely positively not. Even though the material could be cool at times the tests were unclear and the majority of the personnel involved weren't good. I think that this class needs to seriously rethink who their course director is and how they plan on operating the class.
Yeah definitely. As a non science major this was perfect. I learned a ton without feeling completely inadequate in a typical science course.
Yes, I would recommend it to a student who is certain he/she has no interest in majoring in the sciences. It is an interesting, relevant course, and it is not very difficult.

I absolutely recommend this course. It's easy, but still requires you to work (you have to go to the lectures, and study for the exams--people do bomb this course). But if you do the work (really just going to lecture and studying for the exams, no readings), it's a breeze and an ideal science credit.
If you need a science credit and don't want anything difficult, take the class, but examinations are difficult if you don't go to lecture/don't study hard.
Yes, i would because it is a very insightful course that if a student is interested in the study of biology and politics would like very much
If you are a non-science major and are looking for a class that can engage you with how science is applicable in the regular world this is def the class for you.

Great class for non-science majors who need a science credit. If you haven't taken any biology before, I wouldn't recommend it. But it was mostly a review but enjoyed how it was related to today's world and problems.

I would recommend this course to non-science majors who haven't had good biology instruction because this course really helps gain a basic understanding of a lot of biology subjects. I would also recommend it to people who have an interesting the social issues that go along with science since we focus a lot on those in lecture. For students who already know a lot of biology, this course probably won't be exceedingly interesting.
I would definitely recommend this class to another student. I enjoyed learning from different professors, and I liked the way that the workload was not too much of an issue.

Yes, I would recommend this course to students interested in science, but have minimal science background. Covers a great deal of information and interesting topics. Students must be willing to put in a lot of work to study though, because the exams are difficult
This course was so much fun. I really enjoyed it. The lectures were interesting, the exams were fair. Take it if you need a SC and you're a Hu/So kinda person.
If you need a science credit and hate math. Otherwise I far enjoyed my experience with physics!
If you are interested in biology in general then this is the course for you as it highlights a wide variety of topics that you would never cover in a general biology course.
A great science credit for non-STEM majors.  It keeps you engaged and the workload is minimal.

This is a great, low workload science credit for people to become more aware of the somewhat serious biological social and political issues in the realm of science, currently. You really only learn the least amount of science to hammer in the concept. BUT again beware! as the exams are highly short term memorization based and can really get someone if they didn't study everything for the exam.
I would recommend this for a science credit. It's pretty easy and interesting, I thought.
Yes, but it is NOT A GUT. Be warned.
A great science credit that is interesting and not too difficult.
Yes I would recommend this course. Good Science credit.
I would definitely recommend this course - it is interesting, relevant and you learn a lot. Additionally, it is not too much work every week.
I would only recommend this course to someone who doesn't mind heavy memorization and cares somewhat about politics and economics and is also looking for a science class.
yes, its an interesting way to learn about many issues in science
Not particularly. It wasn't particularly engaging, and the subject material was too broad to feel very useful, or like you learned something
Yes, if theyre a humanities major looking for a science credit
Yes, absolutely.
Not a huge workload but I wouldn't really say this is a gut, in terms of grades. I found the class material interesting but didn't do as well as I would have liked to/expected.

Yes, I would recommend this course to another student who needs a science credit. I have never taken biology (even in high school) and I didn't find myself at a disadvantage; this is a good science credit for anyone at any level of scientific background. The midterms are challenging but overall it's a good class.
Yes

Yeah. This course is really interesting topic wise and doesn't take a lot of effort. Carlson is amazing! His jokes are perfectly terrible and he shows he cares about the class while at the same time acknowledging that its definitely a gut science. The other lecturers are fine but Carlson's the man.
Yes, a must take for non stem majors
Would recommend, but don't be fooled. the class is considered a gut, but you definitely have to study for the exams, do section readings and participate, and there is a research paper at the end.

I'd definitely recommend this course if you're polisci/humanities/etc- so many people in this class had no basic knowledge about science (ex. what is an amino acid?) which should be required for people going out into the world! Lack of stem literacy seems to be a really big problem in the US, even for smart people. The amount of work is not much (3 exams + 1 paper), the section discussions are interesting (Anna is the most fantastic TA if you can get her), and you learn a lot of interesting information.
Yes. The lectures are interesting and the course plan is pretty straightforward. It's a good science for non science majors course.
Yes

This course is great with regards to giving you a quick introduction into many diverse subject within the realm of biology. But, be warned: THIS IS NOT A GUT! Sure it is designed for non-science majors, but it is still a difficult course. If you (like me) are pretty much allergic to science, this is perhaps not the course for you. In this course, you cover many scientific concepts in rather great detail. This requires you to take the class seriously and study a lot for the exams. If you are a non-STEM major and are interested in getting to know some real science, go ahead and take this class; it's very well taught and the TAs are great. If you are looking for an easy science gut, however, this is not the class for you.
I would not recommend this course. It is too hard to do well as nothing prepares you for the parts of the class that are actually graded and the tests are too hard to understand.
This class is a pretty interesting science credit. i would recommend.
This is a great way to get a science credit. It is not boring but also very doable for a non-science major.
This class is rooted in rote memorization, and I would not recommend it to a student looking to critically engage with science concepts. I deeply regret taking this course.
YES, definitely as a science credit for non-stem majors. It's engaging but the workload is light!

No. The class is oriented around the education non-stem majors about science, but doesn't make the structure conducive to success. The lack of specificity is actually more confusing. In addition, the tests are such a surprising test of knowledge -- they required specific and arbitrary information rather then general understanding of the material.
Yes

Yes, if you're looking for an easy fifth credit, take this class. If you've taken AP Biology in high school, you will do fine in this class without any problems at all. If you're looking for something intellectually stimulating, though, stay away!
Yes, if you need a science credit.
Good science course for a non science major
Absolutely! A very enjoyable science credit.

I wouldn't take this class unless you're good at memorizing large amounts of information, particularly seemingly obscure details. All in all there are easier and more informative ways to get the SC credit.
Yes, I would because it presents scientific topics in a way that is relevant to your life.
No if you need a science credit I think there are much better classes.
I would not recommend this course unless you are very good at memorizing things. The exams were really unfair and in sections, you don't necessarily go over what you learned in class.
A fair science credit. But there are other more interesting and more challenging ones if you are into that!

Yes. This is a great way for non-science majors to get a science credit. The workload, is minuscule, the readings are interesting, the professor's and TAs are helpful, and the final paper is one of the more worthwhile assignments I did all semester. Plus you'll actually learn something. Over the course of the semester, I found myself referring to course material in daily life. Professor Carlson is a gem, and Rachel (Plumb) is probably the best TA I've had at Yale, so definitely take the course with her, if possible. In all ways, this was an ideal science credit for a non-science major, and in many ways surpassed my expectations.

Take it for a science credit, and you won't regret it. Tests, however, do require a substantial bit of studying, but they are also written for very specific answers, so studying may not always bring you success. The workload is extremely fair in general, and it's pretty interesting.
I would recommend to any non-science student looking to fulfill a credit while enjoying the class.
Yes because it is interesting but it is not an easy A at all.
Yes. It was a delightful course for non-science background students
Only for non-science students looking for a manageable credit
Yes, would definitely recommend! Very easy, but also very interesting. I'm glad I took this.
Definitely take it as an easy science course, but still put in the work if you want a good grade! I loved all of the lectures.
I would recommend this course.
Great course for students who struggle with science oriented classes.
Many people said this class was a gut, but it is not. Do not let them play you with this course. You have to study hard to do well on the exams. It's a VERY good class though for non-science majors.
Yes

It was actually quite interesting and not as gutty as other classes that might be offered for science credits. It's not difficult to keep up at all as long as you go to class or get your hands on notes. Stay on top of things though!

I think this is an excellent course for first years who are not sure of what they would like to focus on at Yale (such as discerning between humanities, social sciences, or natural sciences). It introduces you to the intersection of all of these in a non-stressful environment. I recommend it.

Take Issues Approach to Bio! You will not find another course at Yale where the teachers care so, so much about the material. They truly love Biology, and they are really dedicated. If you're a freshman interested in STEM at Yale despite not having an extensive science/quantitative background, take it. If you're an upperclassman looking for a science credit, it's also great. Just take this course.

I would totally recommend this class to any Yale College student! The information was interesting and easy to learn if you studied even at least minimally. All of the information is on the lecture slides so that's super helpful. The lectures are fun to go to and the professors are engaging -- they know that no one in the class is a science major. The information is interesting and pertinent to everyday life because the professors make sure that the biology is connected to issues in society, which we also learn about. The midterm exams were tough and you definitely had to study for them, but there were three of them so plenty of room to improve.
